title: 106_hr816
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments may be included in income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Section 108 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include unpaid child support payments as taxable income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires taxpayers to pay child support under a support instrument for their child, and meet notice requirements in the following calendar year. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" mandates taxpayers to pay child support and receive notice to include the amount in their gross income for the preceding calendar year. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send the notice if available, or no income will be included if no address is known. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" requires taxpayers to include child support payments in their gross income for the preceding calendar year. Any subsequent payments can be deducted in the year they are made. Definitions for "applicable child support payments" and "eligible taxpayer" are provided. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers. This deduction is limited per child for applicable payments remaining unpaid at the end of the taxable year. The deduction for unpaid child support payments under Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is limited to $10,000 per child for eligible taxpayers with adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000 and unpaid child support payments of $500 or more at the end of the taxable year. The term 'applicable child support payment' refers to periodic payments or expenses required to be paid by an individual under a support instrument for the support of a qualifying child during a taxable year. The term 'qualifying child' refers to a child of an eligible individual for whom a deduction is allowable under section 151 for the taxable year. Payments must be delinquent for at least an entire year to be considered applicable unpaid child support payments. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under the Social Security Act. Identification requirements for claiming the deduction include providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of the individual. The deduction under this subsection requires providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child and the individual responsible for child support payments. Cost-of-living adjustments apply for taxable years after 2000. The deduction amounts in paragraph (2), (3)(A), and (3)(B) will be increased by a cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Subsequent payments made after a deduction was allowed must be included in the taxpayer's gross income for that year. The paragraph discusses exceptions to the rule regarding the assignment of the right to receive payments to a State. It defines a support instrument as a decree of divorce, a separation agreement, or a court decree requiring a parent to make support payments for their children. Additionally, it introduces a new deduction for nonitemizers in the tax code. The tax code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will solely retire US public debt, not for other purposes, regardless of other laws.
